utterances: (Soundbite of laughter)
You know, I don't know.
The president's got a Black Ops BlackBerry.
That's going to be really...
(Soundbite of laughter)
Yeah, but they did removeâ€¦.
Really.
But they removed like some G - from what I understand, you can't like ping it for like GPS location.
So I believe GPS types of tracking or chips have been removed out of it.
So I think it is a stripped down and highly secure BlackBerry.

One of the things and you mentioned this earlier, Mario, that the president wants to do - he wants to put everybody on the Internet who wants access to it, and he's trying to expand it into rural areas.
I'm sorry.
My question is, is he trying to push the Internet and technology onto areas and to people who may not really want it?
You know, I don't - that's a tough question.
That's a really good question because, you know, I come from a frame of reference that everybody should want the Internet, that the Internet should be a utility.
The Internet should be like water, it should be like electricity.
So that's hard for me to remove my own bias to answer that question.
However, we have always talked about having a national broadband strategy and that has not been the case.
So the point is there are people who do want it and there may be some people who don't want it, but they don't have that option given to them at this point.

So now we have Americans across the country who are not connected to this high speed Internet and don't understand what it's capable of doing, how it can increase your access to information, your knowledge, start new businesses, create innovation, do research, help education.
Once you get access to it, I believe that does change things.
So, my suggestion is, I'd rather people have the option and choose not to do it than the option not be there at all.

Well, let me ask you this then because the tech sector - because all of this would have to cost money to make it happen whether people wanted it or not, the president's, you know, intentions to expand Internet access nationally.
The tech sector is not insulated from the current economic crisis, I would not think.
So what are you seeing...
No.
As the biggest impact there?
From the tech sector in today's economy?
Yes.
Yeah, just job loss.
It's been a major - I mean, specifically, you're looking at places that are - manufacturing is taking a hit.
Companies are looking to do more with less.

You are seeing just in recent news, other technology companies like HP and others are making some type of adjustments to - not only their work force but also to their strategies, in a good way though.

And I think right now what we're finding is that, I think this - the technology industry though, Tony, you can't - this country, businesses, the ecosystem cannot function without information technology.

So you have companies like HP, Dell, Microsoft, Google, they're all being very creative now or I would say, more creative than I guess that they had to have been in the past to really understand how they can make the largest impact without it affecting their employee work force.
And I think today's times are making people more innovative and the mother - mother's the necessity of innovation and I think it's just making people be more creative now.

I'm hoping that the stimulus package with having a chief technology officer in house, with $7.2 billion going towards - from the stimulus, going towards broadband, with another $19 billion going towards health information records and technology, and health care.
The dean here, Dr. John Rock, has long worked in medical education, at Johns Hopkins and as chancellor of Louisiana State University's Health Sciences Center.
Starting a new medical school, he says, gave him and other educators a chance to try something innovative: a community-based medical curriculum.
Yeah, well, he comes from Washington, D.C.
and he was the, I believe, I hope I have the title right, but I believe he was the CIO which would make him the chief information officer in Washington, D.C.

So he comes out of that program and, you know, one of the interesting things that he did to early on was he invited the community to get involved in technological issues and policy within Washington, D.C.
So, I do believe that this is going to make a - I think he's going to have a tough job ahead of him, seriously a tough job ahead of him.

A lot of people are wondering exactly what the role should be and what the role should be about, but nonetheless, the fact is we have someone in that position now and it's a good thing for the country.
You are absolutely right that he is going to have a big job, if you even look at just the fact that people are having difficulty converting from analog to digital television...
That's right.
(Laughing)
A third of those conversions have taken place and already...
That's right.
FCC has gotten...
Two days ago, February 17th and you are absolutely right, Tony.
And they've gotten thousands of complaints and questions about that.
Mario Armstrong, thank you very much.
Thank you, Tony.
I appreciate the time.
That was Mario Armstrong, our regular technology contributor joining us from the studios of the Baltimore Sun.
We'll now hear from the StoryCorps' Military Voices Initiative, one of the thousands of conversations with veterans and their families that's recorded all across the country.
Today, one seriously tough veteran Susan Ahn Cuddy, a Navy gunnery officer who served in World War II.
Her children, Flip and Christine Cuddy, came to StoryCorps to remember her.
Mom basically was a trained killer.
She's a much different parent than...
(Laughter).
...You know, someone who owned a bakery.
As a mother, she was really unusual.
She'd been through so much.
Teaching guys how to shoot is like, what do you need to teach a kid?
You know, go out and play.
Yeah.
She had, like, her own code.
And if somebody was really an idiot, you know, she would say they were limited.
That was one of her most heavy-duty criticisms.
Yeah.
She was tough.
Tough.
As soon as they bombed Pearl Harbor, she signed up to join the Navy.
She was qualified to go to officer training school.
But because she was Asian, they wouldn't accept her.
Mom said she didn't care.
She enlisted anyway.
Right.
And, you know, then they accepted her.
You know, it was a white world.
And if you wanted to do anything, you just had to forge ahead.
So she was the very first woman gunnery officer teaching air combat tactics.
These ace pilots would have to come back for refresher courses.
Well, she loved to tell the stories about when she would talk to these guys.
I mean, she was a 5-foot-1 little Asian woman.
There was one incident when this guy comes in, and mom gives him the training.
And, you know, she talks about when you're going to start shooting.
So this guy goes, I'm not shooting until I see the whites of those Japs' eyes.
She said I don't care what you do up there, but when you're down here with me, you do what I tell you to do.
Yeah.
How do you want people to remember mom?
Obviously, you know, when you're growing up, it's just your mom.
But I remember after she died reading her biography and just thinking, my God.
I mean, how do you describe a person like that who's a leader and successful at everything she does?
